ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the basics of creating a well-structured musical, using examples of famous musicals and musicals which Marsha herself wrote. I learned to think about musical theater more critically -- one of my favorite classes was when we discussed the merits of famous musicals, and what could be deleted from them. It was a great exercise in editing, and it is a skill I will continue to use throughout my writing career.
Basic knowledge of the structure of musicals.
Financial inside into the theatre and the role of writers and their input in the process.
This course taught the basics of musical theatre structure, and was primarily a hands-on opportunity to develop a show and receive feedback on your work.
Gained greater insight into how the professional world of theater operates, and had a space to delve into and flesh out our stories.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: This class, while interesting (and certainly fun), was largely disorganized. There were no real assignments, at least beyond ones mentioned in passing in class. There was no definitive grading system, at least that the students were privy to. There was no reading or material to consume to further our learning, instead, we were undirected for the week until the next class.
Access to Marsha is probably the best part of this course. She's a very unique figure and has many fascinating things to say about musicals, life, and theater.

Strength: Marsha Norman is sooooo entertaining. I love every single moment I was in class. 

Weaknesses: You don't really get much as she just talks about her life and not really how to write a libretto
I would say that this class is very much what you make of it. If you are excited about an idea and out in the time to create something every week, you will have a great experience.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this class to someone who is interested in spending time with Marsha, who is an incredibly fun, vibrant professor, but if they were interested in actually leaving the class with a cohesive or comprehensive final composition, I don't think I would recommend it. Without a great deal of time and individual drive, it's difficult to leave the class with a put-together piece.
I would cautiously recommend this course. The homework is not often clear, and the lessons are sometimes unorganized, but Marsha is an amazing librettist.
Yes, I think that if you need a 5th credit, this class is great. Low time commitment, you have fun with the professor, and it's a class to take for the Marsha experience.

If you are interested in creating a work of musical theatre, then absolutely! This course was a great opportunity to focus on a creative project and receive constructive feedback. The classes were not very structured  every week, we would each be asked to provide an update on our show, whether that was a lyric, a scene, or an outline. I felt very motivated to create something new for every class and loved hearing the ideas/projects of those around me.

I found the course very helpful. It's not highly structured, which I liked and found helpful. I enjoyed the conversational explorations of our work and the weekly updates on everyone's personal projects.
